SENT.plain: Background: Aberrant expression of the RON receptor tyrosine kinase is associated with tumor progression and carcinogenesis
The aims of this study were to determine the role and functional mechanisms of RON in Burkitt lymphoma (BL) and to document its potential as a therapeutic target
Methods: RON expression was determined in BL cell lines by western blot analysis and examined in human lymphoma specimens by both western blotting and immunohistochemistry
The correlation between RON expression and Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection was investigated

Raji cells were treated with the Zt/f2 anti-RON mAb and cell viability, colony formation, apoptosis and cell cycle arrest were measured in vitro using cell proliferation assays, colony-forming assays and flow cytometry
Downregulation of RON by Zt/f2 was validated in mice bearing Raji cell xenografts
Results: Immunohistostaining showed a high frequency of RON (+) cells in BL tissues and RON expression strongly correlated with EBV positivity
RON downregulation significantly decreased cell proliferation and colony formation via promotion of apoptosis and cell cycle arrest in Raji cells
The in vivo study showed that RON knockdown inhibits the tumorigenic potential of Raji cells in nude mice
Conclusions: RON acts as an oncogene in the carcinogenesis and progression of BL and is therefore a potential target for therapeutic intervention
